dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey B, what a day in the markets, huh? I mean, just *wow*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey B, what a day in the markets, huh? I mean, just wow.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely, A. Uh, the Dow, you know, shot up over 1,400 points by mid-afternoon. I mean, huge day. S&P 500, Nasdaq, all green.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely, A. Uh, the Dow, you know, shot up over fourteen hundred points by mid-afternoon. I mean, huge day. S and P five hundred, Nasdaq, all green.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 5.2%, over 1,400 points, by mid-afternoon on Thursday, while the S&P 500 was down 4.2% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite lost 3.5%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the S&P's actually positive for the year again, which is, like, a big turnaround. So what's driving all this optimism? Is it just the Fed?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the S and P's actually positive for the year again, which is, like, a big turnaround. So what's driving all this optimism? Is it just the Fed?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 is on track for a third straight day of losses, turning negative for the year after briefly turning positive for 2020 earlier this week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the Fed certainly helped. They, uh, predicted a really swift economic recovery from the recession. But also, you're seeing states successfully reopening.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the Fed certainly helped. They, uh, predicted a really swift economic recovery from the recession. But also, you're seeing states successfully reopening.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors also assessed the Federal Reserves grim update on the economy: The Central Bank forecasted a long recovery, with unemployment set to remain high for years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it's not just talk either. We're seeing some of the states that reopened, like Texas, actually report lower new cases, lower hospitalizations. [overlaps] It's like, a glimmer of hope.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it's not just talk either. We're seeing some of the states that reopened, like Texas, actually report lower new cases, lower hospitalizations. It's like, a glimmer of hope.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wall Street is increasingly worried about a second wave of coronavirus infections: Texas, for example, was one of the first states to reopen, but recently reported three consecutive days of record hospitalizations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Exactly! And, uh, what's really interesting is that even sectors that were totally lagging—like airlines, retailers, cruise operators—they've all started to soar. You know, they were left behind for weeks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And, uh, what's really interesting is that even sectors that were totally lagging-like airlines, retailers, cruise operators-they've all started to soar. You know, they were left behind for weeks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Stocks that would benefit from a reopeningincluding airlines, retailers and cruise operatorshave all plunged recently, after having led the market rally in the past few weeks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's, like, a good sign of broad recovery, I guess. But then, you look at the jobless claims... still rising for the tenth week, 1.5 million more last week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's, like, a good sign of broad recovery, I guess. But then, you look at the jobless claims... still rising for the tenth week, one point five million more last week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Weekly jobless claims fell for the tenth week in a row on Thursday, with 1.5 million more Americans filing for unemployment during the week ending June 6.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: True, but the Fed's point is that, while that number is still up, millions *are* finding employment. So, they're seeing the job market downturn being, um, pretty swift.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but the Fed's point is that, while that number is still up, millions are finding employment. So, they're seeing the job market downturn being, um, pretty swift.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While that number continues to decline, millions remain unemployed and the job markets recovery is expected to take years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So it's this dual picture, you know? Previous weeks it was all doom and gloom, S&P was negative, second wave fears. And now this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's this dual picture, you know? Previous weeks it was all doom and gloom, S and P was negative, second wave fears. And now this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Before this week, stocks had continued to rally on optimism about reopening the economy and a faster than expected recovery from the coronavirus recession.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's a definite shift. I think a lot of that earlier pessimism was about, you know, a slower-than-expected recovery. But now those second wave fears, they've, uh, lessened a bit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a definite shift. I think a lot of that earlier pessimism was about, you know, a slower-than-expected recovery. But now those second wave fears, they've, uh, lessened a bit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This week, however, stocks have taken a hit amid rising concerns over a second wave of coronavirus cases.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But then there's this weird thing with big tech, right? Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Google... they've actually been declining, kind of hampering the Nasdaq from hitting new highs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then there's this weird thing with big tech, right? Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Google... they've actually been declining, kind of hampering the Nasdaq from hitting new highs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That helped the Nasdaq hit a new record high on Wednesday, when it closed above 10,000 for the first time ever. Shares of Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Microsoft and Google-parent Alphabet have all been soaring recently, boosting the index higher.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's an interesting one. It's almost like investors are rotating *out* of those safe-haven tech stocks and into, like, the reopening plays. So, it's a redistribution of capital.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's an interesting one. It's almost like investors are rotating out of those safe-haven tech stocks and into, like, the reopening plays. So, it's a redistribution of capital.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With investors rotating out of stocks that would benefit from an economic reopening, big tech shares have made a comeback.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, all in all, a surprisingly good week for the markets then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, all in all, a surprisingly good week for the markets then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely a strong week. Uh, a lot of optimism out there, which is, you know, refreshing to see.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely a strong week. Uh, a lot of optimism out there, which is, you know, refreshing to see.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 is on track for a third straight day of losses... The Dow is set for its biggest single-day drop since March.
